Description.val:
All aviation spares requirements are developed using accredited sparing models. Funding requirements for major avionics are calculated on an item-by-item basis where possible. APN-6 is a "follower" account providing spares for end-items and modifications procured under APN Budget Activity (BA)'s 1-5 and 7, and follows program changes in end-item quantities, basing scenarios, and maintenance data.

The Initial spares category includes all repairable and consumable allowances to support the quantity and Type/Model/Series (T/M/S) of aircraft in new procurement, during Interim Contractor Support (ICS) to support the Repair of Repairables (ROR) prior to Material Support Date (MSD) and to support aircraft modifications.

Initial spares supporting aircraft procured under APN BA-1 through BA-4 are based on the number of aircraft being procured, basing plans, flying hours, maintenance data, and a number of other data elements derived from the Weapon System Planning Documents and Aircraft Program Data File that are fed into the Readiness Based Sparing model and the Retail Inventory Model for Aviation for the determination of spare engine requirements.  Spare engines and engine modules are procured under initial spares during the production of the aircraft and do not transition to Navy Working Capital Funds (NWCF).

The Initial spares category funds the ROR (9401) via contractor support, prior to the MSD, at which time repairs are turned over to the organic depots.

Modification spares (9504) follow the APN BA-5 Modification budget for all T/M/S supporting various Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) and Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) initiatives.

Spares for Aircraft Support Equipment and Facilities follow the APN BA-7 budget for all T/M/S providing spares for training devices and support equipment (9705-9709).

Replenishment spares provides initial sparing for 6K cognizance material (Cog) containers (9710), Adversary (9711) and Headquarters Replenishment for various programs (9712).  Due to the nature of Adversary and Headquarters Replenishment programs, initial spares requirements are supported for the life of the program by APN-6 funding and are not transferred to the Navy Supply System.

The Replenishment category also funds the Aviation Outfitting Account for Repairables (AOA) (9713) and Aviation Outfitting Account for Consumables (ACA)(9714) for initial sparing and range/depth increases.  

The Outfitting spares element of the budget is comprised of the Aviation Outfitting Account (AOA), which sources spares utilizing Defense Working Capital Fund and NWCF subsequent to MSD, as well as a limited number of Headquarters Replenishment Accounts for spares procured at Naval Air Systems Command headquarters to support Executive Mission helicopters, inter-service support requirements, and miscellaneous aircraft systems.  Successful execution of AOA and meeting Fleet requirements depends heavily on the synchronization between NWCF Buy-In and APN-6 Buy-Out which requires stability of funding levels for both accounts.  AOA fills Aviation and Shore Consolidated Allowances (AVCAL/SHORCAL). AVCALs support carriers and L-decks conducting deployed operations.

Justification.val:
Aviation sparing supports the Chief of Naval Operations' (CNO's) strategy to strengthen naval power at and from sea by maintaining and modernizing a Navy and Marine Corps partnered fleet that is trained and ready to operate and fight decisively in an information domain.  Aviation sparing provides the initial plane-side sparing to fill allowances for authorized allowance listings to better meet today's force demands, to meet naval platform support in a highly data-driven, informational environment, and to meet combatant commander needs. 

AVCAL/SHORCAL requirements enable carriers/L-decks to conduct deployed operations. Initial contractor spares and engine spares are major cost drivers as new Type/Model/Series (T/M/S) continue to be introduced, procured, and modified for technological improvements in FY20.  To field new aircraft, aviation spares support the stand-up of new basing plans and additional support packages.  The aviation spares budget further supports the Secretary of Defense's strategy to improve warfighting readiness by addressing urgent warfighting readiness shortfalls.

(1) Initial Spares:
FY2020 Initial spares funding is required for Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Short Takeoff and Vertical Landing (STOVL) (0152) and JSF Carrier Variant (CV) (0147) to support Initial Operational Capability, meet parts availability, resupply response times, and maintenance requirements, and to continue to progress toward Full Operational Capability. The funding will procure Afloat Spares Packages, Deployment Spares Packages, Base Spares Packages, and the Navy and Marine Corps share of the JSF Global Spares Pool (GSP). The GSP is a foundational tenet of this joint program, whereby the Air Force, Navy, Marine Corps, and eight international countries share the cost of spares, eliminating need for individual entities to procure full depth and range of spares. These initial spares and repair parts are critical to establishing depot maintenance capability and meeting sustainment milestones for all partners. 

FY2020 Initial spares funding includes required support of the following aircraft platforms:
CH-53K (0158) - FY20 increase is associated with additional engine and Contractor spares requirements (LAIRCM AAQ-24, Crypto MODs, and ARC-210).
V-22 (0164) - FY20 funding required for spare engines & components as well as contractor spares requirements aligned to the APN-1 aircraft buys, much of which is due to the Navy variant, CMV-22.
P-8 (0193) - FY20 funding supports procurement of Large Aircraft Infrared Counter Measure System Processor Replacement (LAIRCM) Contractor spares.
E-2D AHE (0195) - FY20 funding required for spare engines & components as well as contractor spares requirements aligned to the APN-1 aircraft buys.
Advanced Helicopter Training System (0344) - funding for engine and contractor spares to align to the APN-3 procurement for the training system. 
KC-130J (0416) - FY20 funding increase due to increase of spare engine and propeller requirements.
MQ-4C TRITON (0442) - FY20 increase is due to a shift in Material Support Date (MSD) from 4QFY20 to 1QFY23 to align to the Initial Operational Capability (IOC), funding will support initial sparing levels for engines, Contractor spares, and PSE requirements.
MQ-8 UAV (0443) - FY20 funding required for engine and PSE spares related to the UAV APN-4 budget.
VH-92A (0455) - FY20 increased funding supports procurement of Contractor spares, Engines, and Peculiar Support Equipment (PSE) aligned to the APN-4 aircraft buys.

FY2020 funding required for Repair of Repairables (ROR) (9401). ROR increase is due to anticipated additional repairs on new parts based on increased number of aircraft in the fleet for platforms such as for MQ-4 TRITON, F/A-18E/F, VH-92, E-2, P-8 and CH-53K.

FY2020 funding for Spares for Modification (9504) supports the modifications for Next Generation Jammer, P-8, Common ECM equipment, V-22, Trainer Aircraft, and AV-8B modifications.

FY2020 funding required for Aircraft Support Equipment and Facilities provides initial spares for Training Devices (9705), Common Support Equipment (CSE) (9707), Consolidated Automated Support Equipment (CASS) (9708), and Tactical Combat Training System (TCTS) (9709).  These accounts are critical and tied directly to enabling T/M/S mission success by training pilots and maintainers and ensuring maintenance and planeside support of the aircraft.

(2) Replenishment:
FY2020 funding increase for 6K (Cog) (9710) due to correlation of container requirement increase as the spares being procured increases.  Adversary (9711) increase due to increased flight hours of the T-38.  Headquarters Replenishment (9712) includes the following platforms: Executive Helicopter Mission, Project Beartrap, E-6B, Direct Support Squadron, and Manned Reconnaissance.  Increase in (9712) FY20 is due to the extension of the E-6 service life and prolonged services hours as well as the number of Executive Helicopter variants that will be in the fleet in FY20 during the transition to the new variant.
  

FY2020 funding is required for replenishment of the Aviation Outfitting Account (AOA) and ACA (9713/9714) spares. The AOA Repairable account is integral in providing sustainment requirements that maintain current operational and wartime readiness for legacy systems such as F/A-18, AV-8B, EA-6B, H-1, MH-53E, MV-22, Common Avionics and Special Programs. Specifically, Aviation Outfitting procures critical initial spare parts to fill AVCAL and SHORCAL requirements in support of the CNO's strategy. Through Outfitting; AOA/ACA funding supports improved aviation operational readiness across the Fleet, fulfilling carrier/amphibious landing deck as well as Naval Air Station allowance growth and supporting repair of AOA assets.  Outfitting requirements increase in FY20 due to CMV-22, F/A-18, H-53, H-60, and Common Avionics requirements increasing to support deployed operations.
